title: Invalid JSON key in metadata causes BigchainDB to crash
body:
## Background
This issue was first reported in the [BigchainDB Gitter chat](https://gitter.im/bigchaindb/bigchaindb?at=5bce5bd5c7bf7c366253f8c9) on October 22, 2018. Including an invalid character (in this case a period) in a JSON key in a BigchainDB metadata object causes a BigchainDB node/network to crash with an internal server error (500). I have tested this with a single node (Docker) and a four-node network installed using the supplied [stack.sh](https://github.com/bigchaindb/bigchaindb/blob/master/pkg/scripts/stack.sh) script. I also managed to inadvertently crash the BigchainDB testnet.

## System specs
Ubuntu 18.04, BigchainDB 2.0

## What caused the error
I had a metadata document that I wanted to include in a CREATE transaction. This document was formatted per the W3C JSON-LD standard (https://www.w3.org/TR/json-ld/). In the "expanded" syntax of JSON-LD, keys can be HTTP URIs. Without realizing that this would be invalid, I posted a transaction to BigchainDB with JSON keys that were URIs. Doing so caused the BigchainDB server to crash. The server responded with the following error:
```
(500, '{"message":"Internal error - interface conversion: interface {}
    is nil, not types.EventDataTx","status":500}\n', {'message': 'Internal error
    - interface conversion: interface {} is nil, not types.EventDataTx',
    'status': 500}, 'http://localhost:9984/api/v1/transactions/')
```
I was unable to bring the server back up after this happened. Using Docker, for example, I had to reset the containers.

However, if the offending JSON key is included in a BigchainDB **asset** (not metadata), then the server responds appropriately with a ValidationError and 400 code and tells me that the period character is invalid:
```
(400, '{"message":"Invalid transaction (ValidationError): Invalid key
    name \\"http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label\\" in asset object. The
    key name cannot contain characters \\".\\", \\"$\\" or null
    characters","status":400}\n', {'message': 'Invalid transaction
    (ValidationError): Invalid key name
    "http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label" in asset object. The key name
    cannot contain characters ".", "$" or null characters', 'status': 400},
    'http://localhost:9984/api/v1/transactions/')
```
So, validation checks do not seem to be enforced for metadata objects!

The error can be reproduced with the following Python script:
```

from bigchaindb_driver.crypto import generate_keypair

BDB_ROOT_URL = "http://localhost:9984"

bdb = BigchainDB(BDB_ROOT_URL)

    "@type": "http://id.loc.gov/ontologies/bibframe/Item"
}}

        "bf": "http://id.loc.gov/ontologies/bibframe/",

        "rdfs": "http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#"
    },
    "@graph": [

            "@id": "http://example.org/ocm05084045#Item050-8",

            "bf:itemOf": [{"@id": "http://example.org/ocm05084045#Instance"}],
            "bf:note": [
                {"@id": "_:N981e348f02414549b1f45d3c4fd27c9f"}
            ],
            "bf:shelfMark": [{"@id": "_:N86583b665c5a48bea6e69601f242ca82"}]
        },
        {
            "@id": "_:N981e348f02414549b1f45d3c4fd27c9f",
            "@type": ["http://id.loc.gov/ontologies/bibframe/Note"],
            "http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label": [{"@value": "First book printed from movable types in Europe; New Testament only from v. 2,in itself imperfect. title: Problem: Events API returns all txs recorded by Tendermint in blocks, including invalid ones
```
body:
We recently realized that if BigchainDB's response to DeliverTx tells Tendermint that a transaction is invalid, Tendermint still records that transaction in its block. (BigchainDB _doesn't_ record invalid transactions in MongoDB.) That's not a bug on Tendermint's part: invalid transactions are needed as proof of Byzantine behavior, so Byzantine nodes can be punished later on. There's a good discussion of this and related ideas in the Tendermint issue https://github.com/tendermint/tendermint/issues/2175 .

## The Problem

Currently, the Events API reports the latest block of transactions _according to Tendermint_, so there might be invalid transactions in that block.

## A Solution Idea

MongoDB now has something like RethinkDB's "changefeeds" called "[Change Streams](https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/changeStreams/)." They were new as of MongoDB 3.6. See "[An Introduction to Change Streams](https://www.mongodb.com/blog/post/an-introduction-to-change-streams)" in the MongoDB Blog. BigchainDB could get a feed of all the latest valid transactions by subscribing to a change stream on [the transactions collection](https://bigchaindb.readthedocs.io/en/latest/query.html#example-documents-from-transactions) in MongoDB.

BigchainDB could return the same info as what the Events API currently returns.

Question: [The docs](http://docs.bigchaindb.com/projects/server/en/master/events/websocket-event-stream-api.html#id3) say that what gets returned is something like:

```js
{
    "transaction_id": "<sha3-256 hash>",
    "asset_id": "<sha3-256 hash>",
    "block_id": "<int>"
}
```
Is that right? If so, shouldn't it be giving the "block_height" rather than the "block_id"?

body:
If I checkout the `tendermint` branch locally and build the server docs, i.e.

```bash
$ git pull

$ make clean
$ make html
```

and I compare the locally-generated HTTP API docs to the same HTTP API docs generated by ReadTheDocs (from the `tendermint` branch), they differ.

Specifically, the example HTTP requests and responses differ throughout the page. It's as if the examples generated by ReadTheDocs were generated using BigchainDB v1.3.0, rather than the latest code in the `tendermint` branch.

Here's a specific example: the very first example, namely the HTTP response from the BigchainDB Root URL. Locally, I get:

```http
Content-Type: application/json

{

    "v1": {

    "AdDuyrTyjrDt935YnFu4VBCVDhHtY2Y6rcy7x2TFeiRi"

  "version": "1.4.0.dev"

```

but if I go to the same page which ReadTheDocs generated from the `tenermint` branch, i.e. at https://docs.bigchaindb.com/projects/server/en/tendermint/http-client-server-api.html 
I see this:

```http
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "api": {
    "v1": {
      "assets": "/api/v1/assets/",
      "docs": "https://docs.bigchaindb.com/projects/server/en/v1.3.0/http-client-server-api.html",
      "outputs": "/api/v1/outputs/",
      "statuses": "/api/v1/statuses/",

    "AdDuyrTyjrDt935YnFu4VBCVDhHtY2Y6rcy7x2TFeiRi"
  ],

  "software": "BigchainDB",
```

Note how the `"version"` is `"1.3.0"`, `"statuses"` is still there, and `"metadata"` is absent: just like the response when using BigchianDB version 1.3.0!

The example HTTP requests and responses are all generated by the helper script in `docs/server/generate_http_server_api_documentation.py` It creates a client using:

```python
client = server.create_app().test_client()
```

where `server` comes from the import at the top, i.e.

```python
from bigchaindb.web import server
```

I think that's where the problem is, but I'm not familiar enough with what's going on with the "old code" versus the code in the new `tendermint/` directory.

Maybe it can't find `bigchaindb.web` locally, so it uses the `bigchaindb` package from PyPI, which is currently version 1.3.0.

title: Fixes #1930
body:
See #1926 & #1930 for background.

# Notes
* Subfulfillment "replay attacks" may still be possible for threshold conditions.  See #1938.
* It was decided to hash the JSON str of a serialized transaction before proceeding further. This choice is based on the notion that it simplifies the data that is being signed, or extended in the case of TRANSFER transactions, in which case the hash is extended with the input tx id and output index. So rather than having a message to sign looking like:

```python
'{"asset":{"id":"fc11b9cac38df80cb435bb925e5998ace2a738453b2be4d06f508de5f8d1207a"},"id":null,"inputs":[{"fulfillment":null,"fulfills":{"output_index":0,"transaction_id":"fc11b9cac38df80cb435bb925e5998ace2a738453b2be4d06f508de5f8d1207a"},"owners_before":["4XYfCbabAWVUCbjTmRTFEu2sc3dFEdkse4r6X498B1s8","JEAkEJqLbbgDRAtMm8YAjGp759Aq2qTn9eaEHUj2XePE"]}],"metadata":null,"operation":"TRANSFER","outputs":[{"amount":"100","condition":{"details":{"public_key":"4XYfCbabAWVUCbjTmRTFEu2sc3dFEdkse4r6X498B1s8","type":"ed25519-sha-256"},"uri":"ni:///sha-256;ZS8-Nzzz5ijP4EduWHdeOiB9gLsdBVNuW3M9ugJYGDs?fpt=ed25519-sha-256&cost=131072"},"public_keys":["4XYfCbabAWVUCbjTmRTFEu2sc3dFEdkse4r6X498B1s8"]}],"version":"1.0"}fc11b9cac38df80cb435bb925e5998ace2a738453b2be4d06f508de5f8d1207a0'
```

one will have something like:

```python
'515af6f534f7e1d0332f0d562eacb70c01e81e0b6f5bb6437c08c00e86b87d06fc11b9cac38df80cb435bb925e5998ace2a738453b2be4d06f508de5f8d1207a00'
```

to be clear, what is above is:

* tx hash before fulfilling: `515af6f534f7e1d0332f0d562eacb70c01e81e0b6f5bb6437c08c00e86b87d06`
* tx (hash) id of input tx: `fc11b9cac38df80cb435bb925e5998ace2a738453b2be4d06f508de5f8d1207a0`
* output_index: `0`

The last two (input tx and ouput index) form the UTXO (unspent output) and taken together make up a unique identifier from the point of view of the entire history of the blockchain. Since an unspent output can only be consumed once, it can only appear once; only in one input, in one transaction. Consequently, appending the utxo to the unfulfilled tx hash should make a unique message, and consequently address the issue (#1930) of not having unique fulfillments, which could potentially allow some kind of "replay attacks", for users overlooking some input(s) in a large complex transaction, made up of several inputs.

# Affected projects
* All clients
* Docs
* IPDB tx protocol (this should really be the other way around)

**UPDATE**: The steps were changed such that hashing is performed once only at the very end. The transaction payload is serialized into a JSON string and extended with the UTXO tx_id and output index if relevant, and the resulting string is hashed into bytes. The bytes resulting from the hashing step form the "message" that is passed to the fulfillment (e.g.: signing step). It should be noted that the message is NOT the hexadecimal digest encoded into bytes, such as in `sha3_256(b'a').hexdigest().encode()` but is rather `sha3_256(b'a').digest()` which is equivalent to `binascii.unhexilify(sha3_256(b'a').hexdigest())`.

title: [tx gen protocol] Non-uniqueness of input fulfillments
body:
# Problem
Fulfillments (signatures) may not be unique for different inputs which are associated with the same condition (public key).

One could imagine a transaction containing a large number of inputs pointing to different transactions and spending outputs belonging to different public keys. Then different users would be asked to provide their respective fulfillment.  Unless a user, or the client software being used, would properly inspect each input to verify that no input is "non-authorized" besides the one input this user is willing to authorize by fulfilling it, a user risks having outputs being spent without authorization by providing one legit fulfillment.

The example below shows a simplified case in which alice's outputs are all spent with identical fulfillments. One output amounts to 100 magiccoins whereas the other one amounts to 1000000 magiccoins. So that would be very bad if alice only intended to transfer 100 magiccoins.

This could arguably be classified as being a replay attack (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replay_attack):

> For example, if a banking scheme were to be vulnerable to this attack, a message which results in the transfer of funds could be replayed over and over to transfer more funds than originally intended. 

# Solution(s)
The obvious solution is that a fulfillment for a given input should be unique. Given the current transaction model the way to make a fulfillment unique for a given input is to make the message that is being signed different for each input. To make the message unique, the utxo (txid + output index) being spent could be appended to the message.

Another approach, which would allow to re-use the same message would be to use prefix conditions, in which the prefix would be unique. One way to make the prefix unique would be to use some kind of "utxo_hash" which would be the hash of the concatenated transaction id and output index. Or just the concatenation of the transaction id and output index.

prefix ocndition: https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-thomas-crypto-conditions-03#section-8.2

>  We can also use the prefix condition in contexts where there is an empty message used for validation of the fulfillment so that we can reuse the same key pair for multiple crypto-conditions, each with a different prefix, and therefore generate a unique condition and fulfillment each time.
>
>   Implementations MUST prepend the prefix to the provided message and will use the resulting value as the message to validate the sub-fulfillment.

In the case of transactions, instead of using an empty message, we would use the entire transaction itself as it is currently being done.

title: Better handling of consecutive transactions

labels.name: make into a BEP
labels.description: Make this issue into a BigchainDB Enhancement Proposal

body:
FYI: I'm treating this as bug, as it's a blocker for us on another project.

To simplify our lives, we did not consider in-block ordering of dependent transactions.
We also do not allow two dependent transactions to be in the backlog at the same time (e.g. HTTP API blocks from submitting a TRANSFER where the CREATE doesn't exist yet).

This yields a frustrating problem that we have to patch in several libraries right now, a loop that waits for a transaction to be confirmed, see [here](https://github.com/bigchaindb/benchmark/pull/1/files#diff-78209855b7c5c0d8253cabe3bc55fc0bR72) or [here (loop at bottom of section)](https://docs.bigchaindb.com/projects/py-driver/en/latest/usage.html#asset-creation).

Instead, I'd like to propose fixing this issue with the following changes:

1. Any schema-valid transaction can pass from the HTTP API into the backlog
  1. Either: The backlog's transactions are topologically ordered, such that when a new transaction gets inserted it gets automatically sorted into place
  1. Or: The backlog is not topologically ordered, such that when a new transaction gets inserted it gets appended to the list of transactions to be processed
2. Upon block creation the node then:
  1. Either: takes the first 1000 transactions (already topologically sorted) from the backlog and puts them into a block. Caution: This will yield unfair results, e.g. when one transaction DAG is very active
  2. or: takes the first 1000 transactions and sorts them topologically and puts them into a blog 

In both cases, this would mean that two (or more) dependent transactions can be in one block.
Bitcoin has this, I remember there was a BIP (can't find it right now). [This link](https://gist.github.com/gavinandresen/e20c3b5a1d4b97f79ac2#canonical-ordering-of-transactions) might be helpful.

FYI: Topological sorting isn't too difficult (meaning that this task shouldn't be too difficult). There are many ready-made algorithms (I [use this one](https://github.com/marcelklehr/toposort) for JS).

title: MongoDB text search does not support Star Wars languages
body:
When creating a text index with MongoDB the index is created with a default language (usually en).
MongoDB also allow us to override the language used to create the text index for a particular document by adding the field `language` inside the document being written. From the [documentation](https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/tutorial/specify-language-for-text-index/):

> If a collection contains documents or embedded documents that are in different languages, include a field named language in the documents or embedded documents and specify as its value the language for that document or embedded document.
MongoDB will use the specified language for that document or embedded document when building the text index

If you specify a language that is not supported by MongoDB the insert operation will fail. This is a problem for us because we don't know how BigchainDB clients will use the asset field.

For example I was testing with star wars data from [swapi.co](http://swapi.co/):
```json
{
  "average_height": "300",
  "language": "Huttese",
  "url": "http://swapi.co/api/species/5/",
  "eye_colors": "yellow, red",
  "name": "Hutt",
  "hair_colors": "n/a",
  "people": [
    "http://swapi.co/api/people/16/"
  ],
  "edited": "2014-12-20T21:36:42.146000Z",
  "homeworld": "http://swapi.co/api/planets/24/",
  "classification": "gastropod",
  "films": [
    "http://swapi.co/api/films/3/",
    "http://swapi.co/api/films/1/"
  ],
  "designation": "sentient",
  "average_lifespan": "1000",
  "skin_colors": "green, brown, tan",
  "created": "2014-12-10T17:12:50.410000Z"
}
```

When trying to insert this asset MongoDB fails with `WriteError: language override unsupported: Huttese`.

We need to somehow either disable language override so that `language` fields in documents do not affect how the text index is built, or default to some language when there is an error.

title: BigchainDB python package(1.0.0) does not work out-of-the-box on a fresh Ubuntu installation
body:
While following the [quickstart guide](https://docs.bigchaindb.com/projects/server/en/latest/quickstart.html), on a fresh ubuntu 16.04 machine, the BigchainDB(1.0.0) package installation i.e. `sudo pip3 install bigchaindb` does not work out of the box and doesn't install the relevant dependencies. 

My machine had cryptography 1.2.3 but cryptoconditions 0.6.0-dev1 is dependent on cryptography 1.9, instead of downloading and upgrading the package the pip install returns with a package conflict error. Similar case with another module pyasn1, I had an older version of it installed on the fresh Ubuntu and the required version was 0.2.3 for cryptoconditions. Resulting in the same package conflict failure.Error message looks like this:

`    pkg_resources.VersionConflict: (cryptography 1.2.3 (/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages), Requirement.parse('cryptography~=1.9')) \ 
Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip-build-blx46w43/bigchaindb `

**Workaround**
Manually upgrade all the packages that `sudo pip3 install bigchaindb` complains about i.e.

`sudo pip3 install [packageName]==[packageVersion]
OR
sudo pip3 install [packageName] --upgrade`

After upgrading run `sudo pip3 install bigchaindb`

**Issue**
Issue is that "cryptoconditions" is part of setup_requires list of setup.py, and due to some race condition using setup_requires and install_requires together, instead of upgrading the package on the system, it only downloads them to the .eggs directory and errors out after that.

- One solution(tested already) could be to remove cryptoconditions from the setup_requires list in setup.py and after that everything works seamlessly, but if we do this the .eggs directory of bigchaindb repo will not have have the egg file for cryptoconditions. Not sure, if that is needed by someone. Everything else starts working seamlessly. @ttmc or @sbellem can comment.

Default read mode is to read from primary node. If the bug occurs, the remaining nodes can not vote for new blocks because they cannot read from the mongodb by run_changefeed function.

The solution is:
```python
            client = pymongo.MongoClient(self.host,
```

body:
[The BigchainDB transaction model](https://docs.bigchaindb.com/projects/server/en/latest/data-models/transaction-model.html) contains a top-level key-value pair:
```json
    "version": "<version number of the transaction model>",
```

What values are allowed for "version"? The schema file at `bigchaindb/bigchaindb/common/schema/transaction.yaml` contains:
```yaml
  version:
    type: string
    pattern: "^0\\."
    description: |
        BigchainDB transaction schema version.
```

What will happen if someone puts "1.0" as the value for "version"?

title: get_unvoted_blocks doesn't reflect changelog order
body:
When the vote pipeline starts up, it calls `get_unvoted_blocks` to get blocks that it missed voting on. This has some issues:

* The order of the blocks that is returned doesn't reflect changefeed order
* This is alot of useless work for a node joining the federation, their votes won't count since they wont be part of block voters list

Possible solutions:

* Remove this; if nodes miss out on changefeed events, they won't vote on blocks they missed
* Have nodes walk existing votes to extrapolate correct changefeed order via `previous_block`.
* Order by block timestamp; won't be 100% the same as changefeed order all the time but it'll be pretty good.

This is non critical really... It's incorrect but it shouldn't result in an invalid state.

title: Possible to create valid block via sybill
body:
[Example](https://github.com/bigchaindb/bigchaindb/commit/39f689e8de95042ef2ee4586ee799d00207ffe04)

Relates to #1166 

Problems:

* Possible to create block listing fake nodes as voters which is then voted VALID, ie, voters don't validate block voter lists against their own voters
* Invalid votes (wrong signature) are counted such that they affect voting outcome, so any node with database access can DOS the system.

Solution:

Block is VALID if:
* Majority (>50%) of ELIGIBLE votes say VALID & agree on previous block
* OR: Dependent (later) block is valid (a vote on a block is an acknowledgement of validity of previous blocks) (this is new)

Vote is ELIGIBLE if:
* Is only vote from node n for block b
* Signature matches pubkey and payload
* Is in block voter list
* Is in federation keyring (this is new)

title: MultipleVotesError when there are votes from unknown nodes
body:
See [example](https://github.com/bigchaindb/bigchaindb/commit/89d816055418dcb3c3d3227a03015f8c870df9f7)

Each block contains a list of public keys which are the voting nodes for that block. If there are more votes than voters in the block, an exception is thrown:

> bigchaindb.common.exceptions.MultipleVotesError: Block cfbfb0b125e1f6cba22bf97ecf5ae2c10df76deb525216cbc79137e204347907 has 11 votes cast, but only 1 voters

Well behaved nodes should not vote for a block where they are not part of the voters set. But this is a sybill attack vector which we can protect against.

title: Backlog transactions can go through block pipeline many times
body:
Resolves #1140, Related to #1150

1. Tx goes into backlog
2. After 120 second, Tx is reassigned.
3. Changelog now includes same transaction twice, so it is considered many times for inclusion.
4. In the case of TRANSFER, double spend is detected. In the case of CREATE, the transaction is erroneously included multiple times.

Proposal:

* Don't listen to backlog changefeed
* When a transaction is picked up for inclusion, refresh the timestamp in the backlog.

title: Transaction already in valid block is not checked
body:
Solves #1140 

During the process of creating a block, we do not check if transactions have already been included in a valid block. This is not an issue for TRANSFER transactions because a double spend would be detected, but it is an issue with CREATE transactions because they do not generate double spends.

Edit: It COULD be an issue for transfers, where the same transfer is submitted twice and not identified as a double spend. See #592 

Outstanding question: Should this be part of the `models.Transaction.validate()` method? Should validate() called on an existing, already included transaction check that it has not been included? The description is then incorrect, it would be more correct to then call the method: `is_eligible_for_inclusion`.

title: Bug/787/secondary index on outputs
body:
resolves #105 
resolves #787 (partially?)

#### Changes
Added secondary index on `owners_after`: used by `get_unspents`.
Added secondary index on `input`: used by `get_spent`.
Renamed `get_owned_ids` to `get_unspents` to follow the language agreed on the api. `get_unspents` now accepts a list of keys instead of a single key. This way we can check if a subset of keys exists in `owners_after` instead of only one key. The logic was also simplified
Example:
```python
{
    'id': 'txid1',
    'conditions': [
        {
            'cid': 0,
            'owners_after': [user1]
        },
        {
            'cid': 1,
            'owners_after': [user1, user2]
        },
        {
            'cid': 2,
            'owners_after': [user1, user2, user3]
        }
    ]
}

b.get_unspents([user1]) # this returns cid 0, 1 and 2
b.get_unspents([user2]) # this returns cid 1 and 2
b.get_unspents([user3]) # this returns cid 2
b.get_unspents([user1, user2]) # this returns cid 1 and 2
b.get_unspents([user2, user3]) # this returns cid 2
```

#### Benchmarks
This measures the performance of `get_owned_ids` and `get_unspents` on a set of 25k, 50k, 75k and 100k assets randomly assigned to a public key in a 500 key pool.
Also each particular asset may be assigned to between 1 and 3 users also chosen randomly.

This tests were done on a single node `m3.2xlarge` ec2 instance running this script https://gist.github.com/r-marques/123e4f788b946f720262e0cc793b1bc1

| # assets | v0.7.0 (db) | v0.7.0 (bdb) | this brach (db) | this branch (bdb) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 25k | 0.177 | 18.029 | 0.032 | 15.453 |
| 50k | 0.206 | 50.192 | 0.026 | 26.844 |
| 75k | 0.231 | 92.609 | 0.039 | 28.462 |
| 100k | 0.239 | 150.835 | 0.023 | 42.488 |

The values are the average call time in seconds for the database query (**db**) and the bigchaindb method (**bdb**)

The secondary indexes speed up the database queries about 10x but most of the time is being spent on the bigchaindb side to make sure that all returned unspents are not in invalid blocks.
Although the changes make the call about 2-3x faster we need to revisit the election code to speed this up.

title: Double spend shouldn't be included in a block (block voted invalid)
body:
See this line: https://github.com/bigchaindb/bigchaindb/blob/master/bigchaindb/consensus.py#L161

So the following scenario:
1. I create a spendable asset `create_transaction('create')`
2. I create a transfer transaction to spend the asset `create_transaction('transfer')`
3. I sign and write them both. They go through and end up in valid blocks
4. Now  I take the transfer-tx from step 2 and post it to the backlog again.

The voters will now run `validate_transaction` or `is_valid_transaction` (same methods in the end), that will see that the transaction posted in step 4 has the same `id` as the one already included in step two.

So in the line mentioned in the beginning:

`if spent and spent['id'] != transaction['id']:`

spent will be the `{'id': <txid of tx in step 2>, ...}`. It evaluates to `True`.
For `spent['id'] != transaction['id']`, `spend['id'] will be the`id`from the transaction of step 2, while`transaction['id']`will be that exact same`id`, which means the above boolean statement will evaluate to`False`meaning a`DoubleSpend` error is not thrown.

This means that a transaction will be included in a block, the voter-logic though will - by checking `validate_transaction` again - see that the transaction has now been spent twice https://github.com/bigchaindb/bigchaindb/blob/master/bigchaindb/core.py#L312 and vote the block `invalid`.

Still, a double spend shouldn't even reach a block as this could be used for DDOSing a BigchainDB network.

title: Improve security of CREATE transactions
body:
Currently, `CREATE` transactions can issue assets for every public key and they are only validated by a single node. 

What would be better:
- only create assets for your personal key
- have the asset creation signed off by at least `n / 2 + 1` nodes

The proposed workflow could be as follows:
1. A client sets up a `CREATE` transaction.
2. The `CREATE` transaction has an implicit condition, as there is no input to the transaction:
   - `n / 2 + 1` out of `n` threshold condition for the nodes
   - The above output goes into a `2 - 2` threshold condition together with the signature of the client
3. The fulfillment of the `CREATE` transaction fulfills the implicit condition above and the nodes validate whether the public key matches the one of the client.
4. The output condition only requires the public key of the client

title: Transaction malleability of transactions containing no signatures
body:
Some transactions might not contain any signatures and that makes them malleable.

For example, if a TRANSFER transaction only has to fulfill hashlock or timelock conditions (or some combination of them), then it doesn't have to contain any signatures.

That means that the receiving node could change some things in the transaction, recompute the transaction id/hash, and it would still be a valid transaction. The receiving node would then write the modified transaction to the backlog.

It's not clear if this problem is specific to TRANSFER transactions, as the question of who should/must sign CREATE transactions is still undecided. For example, see issue #347

title: Voter is not validating blocks correctly when checking for double spends
body:
When a voter is validating a transaction it checks if the input of a transaction was already spent. To check if the input was already spent it checks if there is any transaction in the bigchain that already used that input. Since when voting the block is already in the bigchain it considers the first transaction using that input has a double spend.

We need to add a check so that the voter does not consider the current block when checking if there is already a transaction in the bigchain with that input.

title: Change instructions for installing pip3+ on Ubuntu 14.04
body:
The current instructions for installing pip3+ on Ubuntu 14.04 (in Section 1.3.1 of the docs) do install pip3+, but it's a really old version of pip3 (which causes problems), and there are issue with upgrading it. We found that the following is a much more reliable way to install a recent version of pip3+:

``` text
sudo apt-get install python3-setuptools
sudo easy_install3 pip
```

Bonus: Using this, the `pip` command is actually the Python 3 version of pip, which is the version we want to use. (You can check the `pip` version using `pip -V`.)

title: Fix some config issues for docker-compose
body:
Since containers are ephemeral, the config file that gets created under `~/.bigchaindb` will be wiped out along with the container each time a new container is started.

We need a way to mount this file, or to only rely on environment variables, which would be probably easier.

For the time being this PR is a workaround, such that it mounts a docker specific config file from the host.

Addresses issue #36.
